sections.section: This tutorial demonstrates how to use a Workload Management Policy to control the maximum throughput of a message flow. This use of a Workload Management Policy is particularly useful when backend systems that a message flow interacts with are unable to keep up with a workload sent from a requesting application.
This tutorial provides a message flow that performs a simple transformation of an XML input message received over HTTP before sending a reply to the requesting application.

If you are using Developer Edition, which restricts message processing to 1 message per second, or your system is unable to process messages through the flow at a rate that exceeds 1 message per second then you will not be able to observe the effects of attaching a Workload Management Policy that is demonstated by this tutorial.

sections.section: Click Import to add an application called WorkloadManagementApplication to your workspace.
The WorkloadManagementApplication application contains the following resources.

details.details: WorkloadManagementFlow a message flow that receives an HTTP message, performs a simple transformation and then sends an HTTP reply.
MaxRate1.xml a Workload Management Policy that sets the maximum message processing rate to 1 message per second.
TestMessage.xml an XML input message to test the message flow with.

sections.section: Once you import the tutorial the WorkloadManagementApplication application is ready to be deployed and tested. Before you do this you will create the Workload Management Policy as described under the Prepare tab.

sections.section: Before deploying the WorkloadManagementApplication application you will create the Workload Management Policy which you will later attach to the WorkloadManagementFlow message flow when you run the scenario.

A Workload Management Policy can be created using the Web Administration Tool or by using the command line. This tutorial provides an XML file called MaxRate1.xml which you will use to create a Workload Management Policy called MaxRate1 using the command line. You will later apply this policy to the WorkloadManagementFlow message flow to ‘throttle’ its throughput to 1 message per second when you test the scenario.
To create the policy complete the following steps:

details.details:
Type in the following command to create a Workload Management Policy:
mqsicreatepolicy TESTNODE_userid -t WorkloadManagement -l MaxRate1 -f {WorkspacePath}/WorkloadManagementApplication/Policies/MaxRate1.xml
where
{WorkspacePath} is the location of your current Toolkit workspace.

sections.section: Deploy the WorkloadManagementApplication to the Integration Node
Deploy the WorkloadManagementApplication application by clicking on Deploy.

sections.section: To test the scenario, you will use two separate IBM Integration Console windows. In one console window you will generate a workload of messages and observe the message processing rate. While that workload is being processed you will use another console window to attach the Workload Management Policy that you created earlier to the WorkloadManagementFlow message flow.

The PerfHarness Test Tool is used to generate a workload of HTTP request messages that are processed by the WorkloadManagementFlow message flow. You will need to download and install the PerfHarness tool from the link below. Once PerfHarness is installed generate the workload of input messages by completing the following steps:

details.details:
Check which port the default integration server is listening on for HTTP requests by running the following command:
mqsireportproperties TESTNODE_userid -e default -o HTTPConnector -n port

In the console window run the PerfHarness Test Tool by typing the following command:
java -ms512M -mx512M -cp {PerfHarnessInstallPath}/perfharness.jar JMSPerfHarness -tc http.HTTPRequestor -rl 90 -jh localhost -jp {HTTPPort} -mf {WorkspacePath}/WorkloadManagementApplication/TestMessages/TestMessage.xml -wi 10 -to 10000 -sh false -ws 1 -dn 1 -sc BasicStats -ss 5 -nt 1 -ur wlm
where,
{HTTPPort} is the port the Integration Server is listening on for HTTP requests from the previous step
{PerfHarnessInstallPath} is the location in which perfharness.jar is installed
{WorkspacePath} is the location of your current Toolkit workspace.

PerfHarness will run for 90 seconds and output the message rate at which it is processing messages. The actual message rate achieved is dependent upon the performance of your system but it needs to be in excess of 1 message per second for you to observe the effects of applying the Workload Management Policy in this tutorial.

sections.section: Apply the Workload Management Policy to restrict the message throughput
Use the MaxRate1 Workload Management Policy to restrict the throughput of the WorkloadManagementFlow message flow by completing the following steps:

details.details:
In the console window attach the MaxRate1 policy to the WorkloadManagementFlow message flow by typing the following:
mqsiattachpolicy TESTNODE_userid -e default -k WorkloadManagementApplication -m WorkloadManagementFlow -t WorkloadManagement -l MaxRate1
After attaching the Workload Management Policy observe that the message processing rate in the IBM Integration Console window running PerfHarness has dropped to approximately 1 message per second.
